title: Torrential rains displace thousands in Mozambique as floods wreak havoc

originalTitle: What we know about Trump's  'framework of future deal' over Greenland
title: A Giant Icy Island: Why You Can't Buy a Country!
content:
Hello, hello, my super curious friends all across Africa! It's your friendly reporter here, ready to whisk you away on an amazing adventure to a land far, far away. Get ready to hear about a HUGE, icy island and a very interesting story about why you can't just buy a whole country like you buy a sweet treat! It’s a tale about choices, homes, and why some places are just too special to sell.

What is Greenland?

Imagine the biggest island you can ever, ever think of. Now, imagine it even bigger! That’s Greenland! It’s so enormous that it’s actually the *biggest island in the whole world*. Wow! Most of Greenland is covered in a super thick blanket of ice and snow. Brrr! It’s like a giant, white, sparkling wonderland that’s very, very cold all year round. Did you know? An island is a piece of land with water all around it! Greenland is bigger than many countries put together! This land of ice is a truly special place. You might wonder, how cold is it? Well, imagine wearing your warmest jacket, hat, and gloves, and still feeling a bit chilly! The ice is so old and so deep that it holds secrets from long, long ago. It’s a truly magnificent sight, with giant mountains of ice called glaciers slowly moving and sometimes breaking off into the ocean.

Who Lives in This Icy Land?

Even though it’s super cold, people do live in Greenland! They are very brave and strong people called the Inuit. They have lived there for thousands of years and know all the best ways to stay warm and happy. They build special homes, wear super warm clothes made from animal skins, and are amazing at fishing and hunting for their food. They have special traditions and stories about their icy home. Did you know? The Inuit people are very skilled at travelling across the snow and ice, sometimes using special dog sleds pulled by strong husky dogs! They love their land very much, and it’s their special home. Imagine growing up surrounded by icebergs, polar bears, and seals! It's a very different world from many places in Africa, but just as beautiful and full of life.

Who is the Boss of Greenland?

Now, here’s a little secret: Greenland is like a big house, and Denmark is its parent country. Denmark is another country, very far away across the big ocean. Even though Greenland has its own government and makes many of its own rules, Denmark is still the country that looks after it. So, you could say Greenland belongs to Denmark. Did you know? Denmark is a small country in Europe, known for its fairy tales and delicious pastries!

The Big Idea: Mr. Trump Wants to Buy Greenland!

One day, a very important person, the former big boss of a country called the United States of America, Mr. Trump, had a super surprising idea. He looked at Greenland on the map and thought, “Hmm, I want to buy that big, icy island!” Imagine that! Like going to a shop and saying, “I’d like to buy this giant island, please!” It sounds a bit like a story from a comic book, doesn't it? Mr. Trump thought it would be a good idea for his country, the USA, to own Greenland. He thought it would be important for his country to have such a big, special piece of land in the world.

Why Would Someone Want to Buy an Icy Island?

You might be thinking, "But why, why would anyone want to buy such a cold, icy place?" That's a great question! Well, Greenland isn't just ice. Underneath all that ice, there are special rocks and important metals that people use. Also, because of where Greenland is on the map, some people think it's a very important place for ships and for watching what happens in the world. Did you know? Greenland’s melting ice can cause the ocean levels to rise around the world, which is a big worry for many coastal places, including some parts of Africa!

What Did Greenland and Denmark Say?

So, when Mr. Trump asked if he could buy Greenland, what do you think the people who live there and the leaders in Denmark said? They said a big, strong, and clear "NO, THANK YOU!" It was like saying, "My home is not for sale! My country is not a toy you can buy!" The people of Greenland and Denmark were very clear. They said Greenland is part of their family, their history, and their future. You can't just buy a home where people live, where generations have grown up, and where unique animals roam. Did you know? The word “sovereignty” means that a country or a place has the right to rule itself and decide its own future, and no one else can just take it or buy it!

Why 'No'? Because It’s Their Home!

They said "no" because Greenland is not just land; it's a home. It's where the Inuit people have built their lives, shared their stories, and raised their children. It's full of their memories and dreams. You can't put a price tag on that! Imagine if someone tried to buy your school or your favourite park. You'd say no, right? Because it’s important to you and your community. They believe that the people of Greenland should be the ones to choose what happens to their land. It’s about respecting their wishes and their right to decide their own future. Their land is part of who they are.

A Happy Ending: Greenland Stays Home

So, what happened next? Mr. Trump's big idea to buy Greenland didn't happen. Greenland is still Greenland, beautiful and icy, and it's still part of Denmark. The brave Inuit people continue to live in their special home, making their own choices and looking after their land. This story teaches us a very important lesson: every country and every group of people has the right to decide their own future. Homes and countries are not things you can just buy and sell. They are about people, culture, and history. And that’s a lesson for all of us, no matter where we live in this amazing world! Did you know? Greenland has its own unique language, called Kalaallisut, spoken by the Inuit people! Keep exploring, keep learning, and remember to always respect everyone’s home, big or small! Your African reporter, signing off!
summary: A very big boss from America wanted to buy the super icy island of Greenland, but the people there and their parent country, Denmark, said no because it's their home and not for sale.
whyMatters: This is important because it teaches us that every country and its people have the right to choose their own future and that homes are not just things to be bought or sold.
